data.name: CommentingIngress
data.value: {0} allows for commenting on certain page templates, users can markup comments with BBCode's.

data.name: CommentMainContent
data.value:
Introduction

BBCode or Bulletin Board Code is a lightweight markup language used to format posts in many message boards. The available tags are usually indicated by square brackets ([ ]) surrounding a keyword, and they are parsed by the message board system before being translated into a markup language that web browsers understand—usually HTML or XHTML.

BBCode was first introduced in 1998 by the message board software Ultimate Bulletin Board (UBB). This is why BBCode is sometimes referred to as UBBCode.

Purpose

BCode was devised to provide a safer, easier and more limited way of allowing users to format their messages. Previously, many message boards allowed the users to include HTML formatting, a side effect of which was that malformed HTML could disrupt the page's layout, or HTML could be used to run JavaScript leading to XSS attacks.

Supported BBCodes

Here is an overview of the supported BBCode's when commenting on {0}:

BBCode Example HTML Effect
[code]monospaced text[/code] <pre>monospaced text</pre> 
monospaced text
[b]bolded text[/b] <b>bolded text</b> bolded text
[i]italic text[/i] <i>italic text</i> italic text
[u]underlined text[/u] <u>underlined text</u> underlined text
[s]strikethrough text[/s] <strike>strikethrough text</strike> strikethrough text
[left]left align text[/left] <div style=\"text-align:left\">left align text</div>
left align text
[right]right align text[/right] <div style=\"text-align:right\">right align text</div>
right align text
[center]center align text[/center] <div style=\"text-align:center\">center align text</div>
center align text
[quote]quoted text[/quote] or [quote=Jimmy]quoted text[/quote] <blockquote>quoted text</blockquote>

quoted text
[url]http://example.org[/url] or [link]http://example.org[/link] <a href="http://example.org" target="_blank">http://example.org</a> http://example.org
[url=http://example.com]Example[/url] or [link=http://example.com]Example[/link] <a href="http://example.org" target="_blank">Example</a> Example
[color=#008800]Green text[/color] <span style="color:#008800;">Green text</span> Green text
[hr] (Horisontal seperator) <hr />
[email]someone@example.com[/email] <a href=\"mailto:someone@example.com\">
someone@example.com</a>		 someone@example.com
[font=Tahoma]text in another font[/font] <span style="font-family:Tahoma;">text in another font</span> text in another font
[align=right]right aligned text[/align] <span style="text-align:right;">right aligned text</span> right aligned text
[float=right]right floated text[/float] <span style="float:right;">right floated text</span> right floated text
[list] [*]Entry 1 [*]Entry 2 [/list] <ul><li>Entry 1</li><li>Entry 2</li></ul>
  • Entry 1
  • Entry 2

data.name: FrontPageAsideContent
data.value: In principio erat Verbum et Verbum erat apud Deum et Deus erat Verbum.

data.name: FrontPageHeaderContent
data.value:
ExampleCorp is a market leader in example industries

Donec lorem nisi, ornare eu erat ac, ullamcorper blandit ex. Nam imperdiet lacus id tellus tempor ultricies.

data.name: FrontPageMainContent
data.value:
World class example solutions

  • Phasellus pellentesque ornare nisl non dictum. Integer et quam et eros auctor maximus in rhoncus massa.
  • Praesent sed est mi. Praesent porttitor magna eu tortor dignissim.
  • Aenean accumsan orci sapien, non lobortis ex lobortis eget.

Serving example markets

  • Proin aliquam et metus eu scelerisque.
  • Aenean accumsan orci sapien, non lobortis ex lobortis eget.
  • Nunc at nibh tempor, pellentesque quam at, laoreet metus.

Market leaders in the example industries

  • Quisque orci eros, scelerisque non lacinia scelerisque, dignissim nec mi.
  • Donec in ex eu justo interdum interdum.
  • Aenean accumsan orci sapien, non lobortis ex lobortis eget.

data.name: PrivacyIngress
data.value: YOU MUST CAREFULLY READ THE FOLLOWING PRIVACY POLICIES BEFORE USING {0} (THE "SERVICE"). IF YOU DO NOT AGREE WITH THE POLICIES OF THIS AGREEMENT (THE "PRIVACY POLICY"), DO NOT USE THE SERVICE. USING ANY PART OF THE SERVICE INDICATES THAT YOU ACCEPT THESE POLICIES. ANY PART OF THE AGREEMENT MAY CHANGE AT ANY TIME WITHOUT FURTHER NOTICE, SO WE RECOMMEND THE USER TO PERIODICALLY REVIEW THE POLICIES IN THE AGREEMENT.

data.name: PrivacyMainContent
data.value:
Introduction

{0} value our users privacy. The Service users e-mail address or other personal data will not be shared, rented or sold to any third party.

Commitment

We are committed to privacy and support current industry initiatives to preserve individual privacy rights on the Internet. Protecting your privacy online is an evolving area, and {0} is constantly evolving to meet these demands.

Security

Wherever your personal information may be held within the Service or on its behalf, we intend to take reasonable and appropriate steps to protect the personal information that you share with us from unauthorized access or disclosure.

Children's Privacy

The Service is not structured to attract children. Accordingly, we do not intend to collect personal information from anyone we know to be under 13 years of age.

Cookies

The Service do not make use of cookies to track our users except for storing user session-state while visiting the Service. The session-state cookie last 60 minutes after the users last visit and is not intended to be shared with other services.

data.name: QuerySyntaxMainContent
data.value:
Overview

This web site provides a rich query language through the Query Parser; a lexer which interprets a string into a query.

Terms

A query is broken up into terms and operators. There are two types of terms: Single Terms and Phrases.

A Single Term is a single word such as "test" or "hello".

A Phrase is a group of words surrounded by double quotes such as "hello dolly".

Multiple terms can be combined together with Boolean operators to form a more complex query (see below).

Note: The analyzer used to create the index will be used on the terms and phrases in the query string. So it is important to choose an analyzer that will not interfere with the terms used in the query string.

Fields

www.example.com supports fielded data. When performing a search you can either specify a field, or use the default field. The field names and default field is implementation specific.

You can search any field by typing the field name followed by a colon ":" and then the term you are looking for.

As an example, let's assume a www.example.com index contains two fields, title and text and text is the default field. If you want to find the document entitled "The Right Way" which contains the text "don't go this way", you can enter:


title:"The Right Way" AND text:go

or


title:"Do it right" AND right

Since text is the default field, the field indicator is not required.

Note: The field is only valid for the term that it directly precedes, so the query


title:Do it right

Will only find "Do" in the title field. It will find "it" and "right" in the default field (in this case the text field).

Term Modifiers

www.example.com supports modifying query terms to provide a wide range of searching options.

Wildcard Searches

www.example.com supports single and multiple character wildcard searches within single terms (not within phrase queries).

To perform a single character wildcard search use the "?" symbol.

To perform a multiple character wildcard search use the "*" symbol.

The single character wildcard search looks for terms that match that with the single character replaced. For example, to search for "text" or "test" you can use the search:


te?t

Multiple character wildcard searches looks for 0 or more characters. For example, to search for test, tests or tester, you can use the search:


test*

You can also use the wildcard searches in the middle of a term.


te*t

Note: You cannot use a * or ? symbol as the first character of a search.

Fuzzy Searches

www.example.com supports fuzzy searches based on the Levenshtein Distance, or Edit Distance algorithm. To do a fuzzy search use the tilde, "~", symbol at the end of a Single word Term. For example to search for a term similar in spelling to "roam" use the fuzzy search:

roam~

This search will find terms like foam and roams.

Starting with www.example.com 1.9 an additional (optional) parameter can specify the required similarity. The value is between 0 and 1, with a value closer to 1 only terms with a higher similarity will be matched. For example:


roam~0.8

The default that is used if the parameter is not given is 0.5.

Proximity Searches

www.example.com supports finding words are a within a specific distance away. To do a proximity search use the tilde, "~", symbol at the end of a Phrase. For example to search for a "SPARQL" and "rdf" within 10 words of each other in a document use the search:


"rdf SPARQL"~10

Range Searches

Range Queries allow one to match documents whose field(s) values are between the lower and upper bound specified by the Range Query. Range Queries can be inclusive or exclusive of the upper and lower bounds. Sorting is done lexicographically.


mod_date:[20020101 TO 20030101]

This will find documents whose mod_date fields have values between 20020101 and 20030101, inclusive. Note that Range Queries are not reserved for date fields. You could also use range queries with non-date fields:


title:{Aida TO Carmen}

This will find all documents whose titles are between Aida and Carmen, but not including Aida and Carmen.

Inclusive range queries are denoted by square brackets. Exclusive range queries are denoted by curly brackets.

Boosting a Term

www.example.com provides the relevance level of matching documents based on the terms found. To boost a term use the caret, "^", symbol with a boost factor (a number) at the end of the term you are searching. The higher the boost factor, the more relevant the term will be.

Boosting allows you to control the relevance of a document by boosting its term. For example, if you are searching for


rdf SPARQL

and you want the term "rdf" to be more relevant boost it using the ^ symbol along with the boost factor next to the term. You would type:


rdf^4 SPARQL

This will make documents with the term rdf appear more relevant. You can also boost Phrase Terms as in the example:


"rdf SPARQL"^4 "SPARQL Website"

By default, the boost factor is 1. Although the boost factor must be positive, it can be less than 1 (e.g. 0.2)

Boolean Operators

Boolean operators allow terms to be combined through logic operators. www.example.com supports AND, "+", OR, NOT and "-" as Boolean operators(Note: Boolean operators must be ALL CAPS).

The OR operator is the default conjunction operator. This means that if there is no Boolean operator between two terms, the OR operator is used. The OR operator links two terms and finds a matching document if either of the terms exist in a document. This is equivalent to a union using sets. The symbol || can be used in place of the word OR.

To search for documents that contain either "rdf SPARQL" or just "rdf" use the query:


"rdf SPARQL" rdf

or


"rdf SPARQL" OR rdf

AND

The AND operator matches documents where both terms exist anywhere in the text of a single document. This is equivalent to an intersection using sets. The symbol && can be used in place of the word AND.

To search for documents that contain "rdf SPARQL" and "SPARQL www.example.com" use the query:


"rdf SPARQL" AND "SPARQL Website"

+

The "+" or required operator requires that the term after the "+" symbol exist somewhere in a the field of a single document.

To search for documents that must contain "rdf" and may contain "www.example.com" use the query:


+rdf Website

NOT

The NOT operator excludes documents that contain the term after NOT. This is equivalent to a difference using sets. The symbol ! can be used in place of the word NOT.

To search for documents that contain "rdf SPARQL" but not "SPARQL www.example.com" use the query:


"rdf SPARQL" NOT "SPARQL Website"

Note: The NOT operator cannot be used with just one term. For example, the following search will return no results:


NOT "rdf SPARQL"

-

The "-" or prohibit operator excludes documents that contain the term after the "-" symbol.

To search for documents that contain "rdf SPARQL" but not "SPARQL www.example.com" use the query:


"rdf SPARQL" -"SPARQL www.example.com"

Grouping

www.example.com supports using parentheses to group clauses to form sub queries. This can be very useful if you want to control the boolean logic for a query.

To search for either "rdf" or "SPARQL" and "website" use the query:


(rdf OR SPARQL) AND website

This eliminates any confusion and makes sure you that website must exist and either term rdf or SPARQL may exist.

Field Grouping

www.example.com supports using parentheses to group multiple clauses to a single field.

To search for a title that contains both the word "return" and the phrase "pink panther" use the query:

title:(+return +"pink panther")

Escaping Special Characters

www.example.com supports escaping special characters that are part of the query syntax. The current list special characters are


+ - && || ! ( ) { } [ ] ^ " ~ * ? : \

To escape these character use the \ before the character. For example to search for (1+1):2 use the query:


\(1\+1\)\:2
